src:
Trump langer ut: - Et angrep på demokratiet
Donald Trump langer ut mot riksrettsprosessen mot ham.
02 Nov 2019, 01:59 by Marthe Ihle
USAs president Donald Trump holdt natt til lørdag - fredag kveld amerikansk tid - et valgkampmøte i Tupelo i delstaten Mississippi, bare en dag etter at riksrettsprosessen mot ham ble formalisert.
Ikke uventet benyttet han sjansen fra scenen til igjen å lange ut mot de han mener er ute etter å ta ham. Han forsvarte telefonsamtalen han hadde med Ukrainas president Volodymyr Zelenskyj.

Ifølge CNN kalte Trump riksrettsprosessen en «sinnssyk heksejakt» og «et angrep på demokratiet».

- De er så jævla uærlige. Og de sier «la oss bare be Ukraina om hjelp». Og de vil ikke vise latteren, de vil ikke vise sarkasmen eller moroa. Det er fordi de er de kanskje er de mest uærlige personene som finnes, sier Trump.
- En ærlig fyr
Representantenes hus har startet en riksrettsprosess mot president Donald Trump etter at han ba Ukrainas president Volodymyr Zelenskyj etterforske tidligere visepresident Joe Biden. Han skal også ha forsøkt å få Ukraina til å etterforske Bidens sønn Hunter for korrupsjon, som satt i styret til et ukrainsk energiselskap.
Trump hevder videre at han ikke en gang visste Zelenskyjs navn da han ringte ham, og forsvarer telefonsamtalen.
- Jeg ringte en helt ny person, en mann jeg ikke aner hvem er. Jeg visste ikke navnet hans før jeg så på kortet, sier Trump.
Han fortsetter:

- Jeg er uansett en ærlig fyr, men tror dere at når jeg tar en telefon til en nyvalgt president, at jeg ville sagt noe upassende når jeg vet at jeg har alle disse folka på tråden?

Uro
Torsdag ettermiddag vedtok Representantenes hus en resolusjon som formaliserer riksrettsprosessen mot president Donald Trump.
Leder i Representantenes hus, Nancy Pelosi, overrasket med å avgi stemme for å formalisere riksrettsprosessen. Det er uvanlig at lederen selv tar del i avstemningen.
Leder av regelkomiteen, Jim McGovern, omtaler det som en trist dag for USA.
- Dette er en mørk og trist dag i USAs historie, sier han.
Etter at stemmene var talt opp, brøt det ut kaos, ifølge The Guardian. Republikanere skal ha ropt «protest», mens demokrater skal ha bedt dem om å forholde seg rolige.
text:
Trump extends: - An attack on democracy
Donald Trump is leaning toward the judicial process against him.
02 Nov 2019, 01:59 by Marthe Ihle
US President Donald Trump held an election campaign meeting in Tupelo, Mississippi State, on Saturday night - Friday night, just one day after the civil trial against him was formalized.
Not unexpectedly, he used the opportunity from the stage to once again extend to those he thinks are looking to take him. He defended the telephone conversation he had with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyj.

According to CNN, Trump called the judicial process an "insane witch hunt" and "an attack on democracy."

- They're so damn dishonest. And they say "let's just ask Ukraine for help". And they will not show the laughter, they will not show the sarcasm or fun. That's because they are they are perhaps the most dishonest people there are, says Trump.
- An honest guy
The House of Representatives has started a judicial process against President Donald Trump after he asked Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyj to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden. He should also have tried to get Ukraine to investigate Biden's son Hunter for corruption, who sat on the board of a Ukrainian energy company.
Trump further claims that he didn't even know Zelensky's name when he called him and defends the phone call.
- I called a brand new person, a man I have no idea who is. I didn't know his name until I looked at the card, says Trump.
He continues:

- I'm an honest guy anyway, but do you think that when I make a phone call to a newly elected president, that I would say something inappropriate when I know I have all these people on the thread?

Unrest
On Thursday afternoon, the House of Representatives passed a resolution formalizing the judicial process against President Donald Trump.
The leader of the House of Representatives, Nancy Pelosi, was surprised to vote to formalize the judicial process. It is unusual for the leader to take part in the vote.
The leader of the rules committee, Jim McGovern, describes it as a sad day for the United States.
"This is a dark and sad day in US history," he says.
After the votes were counted, chaos erupted, according to The Guardian. Republicans should have called for "protest," while Democrats should have asked them to remain calm.
